Graphical abstract MOFs have open frameworks, modificable stuctures and evenly distributed metal centers, which show unique advantages in metal, organic ligand, and morphology regulation. Therefore, MOF-derived transition metal phosphides (TMPs) exhibit high designability and excellent catalytic activity. It is critical to synthesize high-efficiency electrocatalysts to boost the performance of water splitting to meet the requirements of industrial applications. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) can function as ideal molecular platforms for the design of highly reactive transition metal phosphides (TMPs), a kind of candidates for high-efficiently electrocatalytic water splitting. The intrinsic activity of the electrocatalysts can be greatly improved via modulating the electronic structure of the catalytic center through the MOF precursors/templates. Moreover, the carbon layer converted in-situ by the organic ligands can not only protect the TMPs from being degraded in the harsh electrochemical environments, but also avoid agglomeration of the catalysts, thereby promoting their activities and stabilities. Furthermore, heteroatom-containing ligands can incorporate N, S or P, etc. atoms into the carbon matrixes after conversion, regulating the coordination microenvironments of the active centers as well as their electronic structures. In this review, we first summarized the latest developments in MOF-derived TMPs by the unique advantages in metal, organic ligand, and morphology regulations for electrocatalytic water splitting. Secondly, we concluded the critical scientific issues currently facing for designing state-of-the-art TMP-based electrocatalysts. Finally, we presented an outlook on this research area, encompassing electrocatalyst construction, catalytic mechanism research, etc. Keywords Metal-organic framework Transition metal phosphide Water splitting Electrocatalyst Electronic structure 1 Introduction The worsening environmental problems are seriously affecting the survival and health of human beings. The exploitation of green and sustainable energy is the relentless pursuit of mankind [1]. Hydrogen (H2) is a very promising sustainable and environmental-friendly energy source [2]. Among the developed H2 production technologies, electrolysis of water features advantages such as high conversion efficiency and the ability to prepare high-purity H2, making it an ideal way to access hydrogen energy on a large scale [3–5]. Moreover, tidal, solar and wind energy can provide a constant source of electricity for hydrolysis reactions. Therefore, electrocatalytic water splitting has the prospect of large-scale industrialization [6]. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are the two key reactions that make up the electrolysis of water [7–14]. The reaction mechanisms of two half-reactions vary with the electrolytes. Generally, HER involves three possible steps (Scheme 1 ). In the first Volmer step, electrons are transferred to the surface of the electrode to capture protons in the solution, yielding the intermediates of adsorbed hydrogen atoms (H*, where * represents the catalytic sites of catalysts) on the active sites [11]. In the next step, hydrogen can be obtained in two different ways. When the H* coverage is low, it is likely to couple with electrons and protons to obtain H2 (Heyrovsky step). In contrast, when the H* has a high coverage, H2 mainly originates from the reorganization of adjacent H*, which is known as Tafel reaction. Normally, OER relates to relatively complicated proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) pathways (Scheme 1) [8]. In acidic or neutral media, the initial step of OER is the adsorption of H2O on the catalyst surface and oxidized to form OH* with losing an electron and a proton. Subsequently, OH* is converted to O* after losing the second electron and proton. Then, O* combines with H2O and losses the third electron and proton to form OOH*. Finally, OOH* transfer to O2 with the losing of final electron and proton. In alkaline medium, the first step is that OH – adsorbs on the catalyst surface and losses an electron to become OH*. Subsequently, OH* reacts with OH – and losses the second electron and proton, converting to O* and H2O. Then, O* combines with OH – and losses the third electron to form OOH*. Finally, OOH* undergoes the final PCET to form O2. In theory, the voltage needed to electrolyze water is 1.23 V [8–10]. However, in fact, because HER and OER have sluggish reaction kinetics, which require high overpotentials to accelerate the reaction, the actual applied voltage for water decomposition usually exceeds 1.23 V [8–10]. Therefore, it is pivotal to construct catalysts with high catalytic performance to boost the efficiency of HER and OER. The catalytic efficiency of electrocatalysts can be evaluated through the following key parameters, including Faradaic efficiency, Tafel slope, overpotential, turnover frequency (TOF). Overpotential (η) can provide an additional impetus to break the energy barrier in the electrocatalytic process [15]. Generally, the superiority of the catalyst is usually measured by the overpotential corresponding to a current density (j) of 10 mA cm−2 [8]. This current density exactly matches the efficiency of the 12.3% solar-to-hydrogen, thereby the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 is often compared. Tafel slope is calculated from the linear sweep voltammogram (LSV) curves [7]. The small Tafel value indicates that the electrocatalyst has accelerated reaction kinetics. Faradaic efficiency reveals the efficiency of the conversion of external electrons into products [8–10]. The actual production of hydrogen and oxygen can be measured via gas chromatography. Constant current or potential electrolysis can be used to calculate the theoretical yield of the gases. The ratio of actual output to theoretical output is Faradaic efficiency. TOF is also important parameter to assess the activity of electrocatalysts. Normally, the following formula can be used to calculate the TOF values: TOF = j/(4 × F × n), where n is the molar number of catalytic sites per unit area (mol cm−2), F is the Faraday constant. In addition, another critical index to assess the superiority of a catalyst is stability. The stability of electrocatalysts can also be determined through the constant potential or current electrolysis. If the potential or current density of the catalyst does not change significantly during a long electrolysis, the catalyst has great durability. The electrochemical surface area (ECSA) can evaluate the number of active sites exposed on an electrocatalyst. ECSA can be obtained by the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) method due to their positive relationship, and C dl can be determined by cyclic voltammetry (CV) [9]. Firstly, the CVs at different scanning speeds in the non-Faraday zone are measured. Subsequently, the capacitance currents at their intermediate potentials are linearly fitted to the sweep speeds, and half of their slope is C dl. A larger value of C dl indicates that the catalyst possesses larger ECSA and better intrinsic activity. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) can reveal the charge-transfer resistance (R CT) of an electrocatalyst, which is usually performed in the applied potential range of HER or OER. Generally, a smaller value of R CT indicates a better conductivity of the catalyst. The value of mass activity (A g−1) is equal to the ratio of the current density measured at a specific overpotential to the catalyst loading (mass activity = j/m). An idea catalyst for electrocatalytic water splitting should have the characteristics of high activity, high stability and low-cost. Namely, the catalysts should be fabricated according to the following rules: (1) obtaining large current densities for HER and OER at small overpotentials; (2) outstanding durability for up to several months or years in different media; (3) cheap and available raw materials; (4) simple and scalable synthesis strategies. Up to now, Pt and Ru(Ir)-based substances are recognized as highly active catalysts for HER and OER, respectively [16]. Nevertheless, due to the rarity of precious metals, the industrial applications of these noble-metal catalysts are seriously hampered. Previous studies have found that the abundant transition metal-based catalysts possess great redox properties, and their catalytic activity can be further boosted through rational and effective electronic regulation. Accordingly, it is very urgent to prepare highly active non-precious metal-based electrocatalysts. The inexpensive transition metal-based catalysts primarily comprise homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. The homogeneous catalysts are mainly zero-dimensional (0D) metal complexes [17]. Although these molecular catalysts are beneficial to the study of catalytic mechanisms, low catalytic current density and poor durability are their fatal drawbacks. Compared with homogeneous catalysts, heterogeneous catalysts usually exhibit good stability and large catalytic current density, showing promising prospects. Heterogeneous catalysts mainly include metal hydroxides, oxides, phosphides, chalcogenides, borides, nitrides, etc. [18–31]. Among them, transition metal phosphides (TMPs) are typical representatives. TMPs usually have special crystal structures. The smallest structural unit formed by metal is a triangular prism, where P atoms locate in its internal voids, and the local structure is like a spherical shape, which can expose more coordinated unsaturated surface atoms and present higher density of active sites [32]. Therefore, compared to other transition metal sulfides, selenides, nitrides, and borides, TMPs usually exhibit better intrinsic activity. In addition, P in TMPs possesses more suitable electronegativity, which benefits for keeping the bonding strength of the intermediates neither too high nor too low. Compared with P, the electronegativities of other heteroatoms, such as S, Se, N, are higher, resulting in a relatively strong affinity to the hydrogen intermediate, which is adverse to the HER kinetics [9,11]. The discovery of TMPs can be traced back to the 18th century, but their application value has not been discovered for a long time. Until 1960, the application value of TMPs was discovered and applied to many fields, such as hydrotreating, hydrodesulfurization, metallurgy, lithium-ion batteries, photocatalytic degradation, etc. [33,34]. However, the research of TMPs as electrocatalysts for electrolysis of water appeared relatively late. In 2005, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were applied by Liu and Rodriguez et al. to reveal that Ni2P had both high catalytic performance and high surface thermodynamic stability as the [NiFe] hydrogenase. It was expected to have potential as a great HER catalyst [35]. In 2013, Zhang and coworkers prepared FeP via an anion-exchange method, confirming for the first time through experiments that TMPs were highly efficient HER catalysts [36]. Almost at the same time, Schaak and coworkers demonstrated that the nanostructured Ni2P nanoparticles (NPs) exhibited outstanding HER property. The overpotentials for Ni2P at 20 and 100 mA cm−2 were 130 and 180 mV in 0.5 M H2SO4, respectively [37]. Fig. 1 shows several important events. The earliest research of TMPs for OER dated back to 1989. Kupka and Budniok first demonstrated that TMPs were good OER electrocatalysts [38]. They prepared Ni-Co-P alloys for electrocatalytic OER and revealed that Ni-Co-P was easily oxidized to the corresponding oxyhydroxides during OER. Unfortunately, more than 20 years after this report, the research of TMPs for OER has not made further progress. Until 2015, Yoo and coworkers made a huge breakthrough in demonstrating that the real catalytic active centers of TMPs were the in-situ generated metal oxides/oxyhydroxides. They conducted in-depth investigation into the OER process of CoP and revealed that CoP would be converted into a highly active OER electrocatalyst by performing anodic potential in an alkaline liquid [39]. The characterizations of CoP after OER indicated that the cobalt-oxo/hydroxo scattered into the phosphate-enriched framework. Soon after, a series of highly active metal phosphides for OER have been reported. TMPs for catalytic overall water splitting are relatively new. Until 2015, Hu and coworkers reported for the first time that Ni2P was a great bifunctional electrocatalyst for HER and OER. The electrolytic cell constructed by Ni2P only required 1.63 V at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH [40]. These classic research results guide the rapid developments of TMPs for electrocatalytic water splitting. Up to now, thousands of research works about TMPs for water splitting have been published. The research of TMPs for electrolysis of water has developed rapidly [40–45], but severe challenges still exist: (1) Precise synthesis of catalytic sites. This will be of great benefit for the in-depth investigation of the catalytic mechanism and the significant enhancement of the catalytic activity. (2) Develop facile preparation steps and cheap raw materials to prepare highly active catalysts on a large scale. (3) Enhance the tolerance of the catalysts under extreme pH conditions to meet the requirements of actual industrial applications. Fortunately, the availability of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) seems to provide novel ways to solve the above problems. MOFs are porous crystalline substances constructed from metal clusters or ions with organic ligands [46–50]. MOFs possess high porosity, high specific surface areas, multiple active sites and adjustable structures [51–55]. They are extensively applied in molecular recognition, drug release, catalysis, and gas separation and storage [56–69]. Recently, MOF materials have proven to be very useful precursors/templates that can be derivatized into a variety of nanomaterials with novel micro/nano structures [70–77]. On one side, MOFs contain metal and organic sources, which are representative precursors for constructing functional organic-inorganic composite catalysts. On the other side, MOFs are good templates to regulate the resulting morphology and active configuration. Derivatives obtained by pyrolysis of MOFs can perfectly inherit the original structural characteristics of MOFs, exhibiting uniformly dispersed catalytic sites and a high specific surface area [78–83]. Besides, the formed carbon layers improve the stability of the catalytic centers while also serving to modulate their electronic structure [84–86]. Therefore, MOF-derived catalysts usually exhibit excellent electrocatalytic performances. In 2008, Xu et al. fabricated nanoporous carbon with MOF as a template for the first time, which showed very high specific surface areas [87]. The MOF-derived carbon exhibited outstanding electrocatalytic activity and could be used for electrochemical double-layer capacitors (EDLC). In 2014, Qiao and coworkers first reported a facile and practical MOF-derived strategy to prepare Co3O4-carbon nanowire arrays for OER [88]. The electrocatalyst was constructed via pyrolysis of the Co-naphthalenedicarboxylate MOF grown on copper foil. The outstanding electrochemical activity of Co3O4-carbon nanowire arrays for OER ascribed to the porous nanowire array architecture and carbon incorporation, which endowed the electrocatalyst with enhanced electron conductivity, abundant active sites, and remarkable structural stability. In 2015, Jiang and coworkers first synthesized nickel phosphides for HER by phosphating a nickel-based MOF [89]. The electrocatalyst showed great catalytic performance for hydrogen evolution. Subsequently, great progress has also been obtained in MOF-derived TMPs for electrocatalytic total hydrolysis, and in MOFs to confine the synthesis of ultrafine TMP NPs [90–92]. For instance, Sun and coworkers developed the first case of MOF-derived Co-P/NC electrocatalyst for overall water splitting [90]. The electrocatalyst was produced via directly calcining ZIF-67 and then phosphating. Benefiting from the 3D interconnected large mesopores and the porous carbon encapsulation, ZIF-67-dirived Co-P/NC behaved highly exposed catalytic sites. In 1.0 M KOH, the Co-P/NC catalyst could yield a large current density of 165 mA cm−2 through employing a cell potential of 2.0 V. Li et al. grew Ni-MOF-74 on nickel foam (NF) and then phosphating Ni-MOF-74 to prepare ultrafine Ni12P5 NPs with size of 3–4 nm [91]. The Ni12P5 NPs were encapsulated in carbon layers to protect and stabilize the catalyst in the process of electrocatalysis. Therefore, the as-prepared ultrafine Ni12P5 NPs exhibited outstanding HER activity. Xu et al. prepared highly dispersed ultrafine cobalt phosphide NPs (3–4 nm) via pyrolyzing and phosphating Co-MOF nanosheets [92]. The ultrasmall CoP x NPs exhibited high catalytic activity for overall water splitting, employing a cell potential of 1.63 V at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH. Compared with TMPs synthesized by traditional methods, MOF-derived TMPs exhibit the following advantages (Fig. 2 ): (1) the scattered metal sites in MOFs can be transformed to corresponding TMPs and embedded in the produced carbon layer, which will greatly reduce the catalysts agglomeration, thus fabricating highly dispersed ultrafine TMPs; (2) the carbon substrate converted by organic ligands can not only serve as a conductive network to promote electron transfer, but also stabilize and protect the TMP NPs; (3) ligands are easily to be modified with various heteroatoms, and they can be directly introduced into the derived carbon substrate, which can not only create specific microenvironments for the growth of TMPs, but also can modulate their electronic structures; (4) the configuration, shape and scale of TMPs could be clearly defined through adjusting the types and proportions of metals and organic ligands on an atomic scale. In this review, the latest developments of TMPs derived from MOFs for electrocatalytic water splitting were presented. Firstly, we discussed the effects of P on HER and OER performance. Secondly, we summarized the preparation methods for MOF-derived TMPs. Afterward, we systematically discussed the solutions for enhancing the electrocatalytic efficiency of MOF-derived TMPs. Subsequently, typical cases of MOF-derived TMPs for water electrolysis were highlighted as well. Lastly, we addressed the critical scientific issues currently facing for designing state-of-the-art TMP-based electrocatalysts and presented an outlook on this research area. 2 Effects of P on HER and OER activity Understanding the effect of P on electrocatalytic water splitting in TMPs is helpful to guide the design of highly active electrocatalysts (Fig. 3 ). On one hand, the phosphorus atoms in TMPs can not only capture positively charged protons due to their small negative charge, but also facilitate the removal of hydrogen from the surface. On the other hand, the doped P can make some metals positively charged to facilitate their combination with hydroxyl groups, thereby making them easier to restructure to MOH/OOH during the OER process, as actual high-performance OER catalytic sites. Here, we discussed in detail the influence of P on HER and OER. 2.1 Effects of P on HER In the HER process, the catalytic efficiency of the electrocatalyst is decisively affected through the adsorption energy of H*. Although the coverage ratio of H* in the Volmer step is high, the excessively robust adsorption energy of H* will seriously hinder the recombination of adjacent H* in the subsequent Tafel step, which is not conducive to the generation of H2. On the contrary, if the adsorption energy is too weak, it will not be conducive to the adsorption of the intermediate, resulting in too low coverage of H* in the Volmer step, it is likely to couple with electrons and protons to obtain H2 via the Heyrovsky step. However, the Heyrovsky step has a larger energy barrier compared to the Tafel step. Therefore, catalysts with moderate adsorption energy will show the best HER performance. Since the greater electronegativity of P (2.19) than that of most metal elements, the induction effect can lead to a transfer of a small number of electrons from the metal atom to the more electronegative P after forming the M−P bond, thus making the metal positively charged and P negatively charged [93]. The negatively charged P can act as a proton acceptor to promote the hydrogen coverages. Besides, the incorporation of P can effectively modulate the electron densities on the active surface of catalysts, thereby providing better balance between the adsorption and desorption of hydrogen, which is conducive to the generation of H2 [8,9]. Therefore, doping P atoms into the transition metals can enhance their HER performance [94–100]. In 2014, Wang and coworkers compared the electrocatalytic HER activities of MoP, Mo3P and Mo, revealing that P doping could change the properties of the catalysts, and the more P doping, the better HER activity of the catalysts [99]. DFT calculations demonstrated that doping P into Mo to generate MoP introduced a great ‘hydrogen delivery’ system, where P atoms on the surface would combine H2 at small percentages of coverage and remove it at large percentages of coverage, creating abundant optimal active sites for HER (Fig. 4 ). In 2015, Schaak and coworkers prepared morphologically equivalent Co2P and CoP highly active electrocatalysts for HER [100]. In 0.5 M H2SO4, the overpotentials for Co2P and CoP at 10 mA cm−2 were 95 and 75 mV, respectively. The lower overpotential of CoP indicated that adding the content of P element in the identical metal phosphides could enhance the electrocatalytic performance for HER. 2.2 Effects of P on OER The incorporation of P can make some metals positively charged to facilitate their binding to oxide species with unshared pair electrons, which in turn make the metal atoms more susceptible to oxidation during the OER process [101]. Many studies have shown that the surfaces of TMPs are easily oxidized to generate the metal oxides, hydroxides and/or oxyhydroxides (MO x H y ) under anode potentials in strongly alkaline electrolytes, which are the actual OER active species [101–111]. The MO x H y active species generated by TMP reconstructions are usually low crystallinity or even amorphous with abundant defective sites, such as vacancies, edges, corners, stacking layer dislocations, exhibiting better active site accessibility, which is beneficial to improve the intrinsic activity of the catalysts [109,112]. The unique active structures produced by the reconstruction of these TMPs are difficult to obtain through conventional synthetic methods. Moreover, the outer surface of some TMPs is oxidized to MO x H y , but the core is still highly conductive TMPs. The MO x H y layer with high surface area and porous nanostructure can prevent the further corrosion of the internal TMPs and the formed MP x -MO x H y interface is more beneficial to the transmission of carriers from the inner core to the outer active surface. Furthermore, P in TMPs is usually oxidized to phosphate species, which may assist the proton transfer during OER process, facilitating the catalytic reaction on the electrodes. In addition, part of them can be adsorbed on the surface or doped into the metal lattice of the catalysts and play significant roles in regulating the electronic structures of the metal centers [112]. As a consequence, TMPs usually exhibit excellent OER performance. For example, Ren and coworkers fabricated a highly effective Fe(PO3)2 catalyst on NF for OER [107]. It was found that the formed Ni-Fe oxide/hydroxide and FeOOH promoted the catalytic activity of Fe(PO3)2. Sun and coworkers synthesized Fe-doped Ni2P for electrocatalytic OER [108]. The self-supporting electrode exhibited remarkable electrochemical OER activity. After OER stability test, they found that the catalyst was encapsulated by the in-situ generated NiOOH species. Thus, the improved electrocatalytic efficiency for OER was attributed to the MO x /MOOH(M = Ni, Fe) active sites formed on the Fe-doped Ni2P surface. Qiu et al. fabricated amorphous cobalt iron hydroxide nanosheets through the strategy of electrochemical oxidation of TMPs (Fig. 5 ) [109]. Under alkaline oxidation conditions, the M−P bonds in Co0.8Fe0.2P@C were easily oxidized and converted to cobalt oxyhydroxide-iron, and P was dissolved in the electrolyte. They confirmed that Co0.8Fe0.2P@C was completely reconstructed to Co0.8Fe0.2OOH@C through a series of characterizations. Particularly importantly, Co0.8Fe0.2OOH@C reconstructed from Co0.8Fe0.2P@C showed a lattice distortion and an amorphous structure, which exhibited abundant defects and high active surface areas. However, crystalline CoFe layered double hydroxide (LDH) could only undergo limited lattice distortion and surface reconstruction under the same conditions. Therefore, Co0.8Fe0.2OOH@C showed outstanding catalytic efficiency and durability for OER. In order to explore the formation of the real active species of TMPs during electrocatalytic OER, various characterization techniques have been used. For instance, Yoo and coworkers studied the surface changes of CoP NPs during electrocatalytic OER by extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), X-ray absorption near edgy spectroscopy (XANES), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [39]. The results revealed that the cobalt metaphosphate and oxo/hydroxo units were produced in CoP during OER. Liu and coworkers combined various characterization methods to analyze the structural and compositional changes of metal phosphate during the electrocatalytic OER process [110]. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurement showed that the P content in nickel phosphate gradually decreased and the smooth nickel phosphate nanosheets would become a rough porous structure after OER. Combined with the elemental dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) and high resolution TEM analysis, it could be determined that these in-situ generated crystalline species were nickel oxide. Chen and coworkers first utilized the in-situ Raman spectra to characterize the real active species of Ni2P for electrocatalytic OER [111]. At the oxidation potentials less than 1.35 V, the Raman spectrum of Ni2P did not change significantly compared with the original one. When the oxidation potential was 1.4 V, the characteristic peaks appeared, which were attributed to the Ni–O bond, suggesting the production of NiOOH. As the oxidation potentials increased, the intensities of the NiOOH peaks were remarkably enhanced. 3 Synthetic strategies for MOF-derived transition metal phosphides The synthetic strategies for MOF-derived TMPs mainly contain gas-solid reaction, solid-state reaction, and liquid-phase reaction. The advantages and disadvantages of these strategies are summarized in Table 1 . According to the different sources of P sources, it can be divided into external P sources and MOFs' own organic P sources. As a typical representative of additional P sources, NaH2PO2 is often utilized as phosphorus source in gas-solid reaction [113–117]. When the pyrolysis temperature is higher than 250 °C, NaH2PO2 decomposes to release the phosphine (PH3). Meanwhile, PH3 will continue to react with MOFs or their derived metals/metal oxides to form TMPs. In a typical preparation procedure, NaH2PO2 was located in the vacuum furnace, and MOFs or their derived metals/metal oxides were placed downstream. Subsequently, the tube furnace was programmed to increase its temperature under inert gas flow. At last, TMPs were prepared after naturally cooling to room temperature. For example, Zhao and coworkers prepared Ni2P@C nanoroads by directly phosphating ZIF-67-Ni at 400 °C under N2 flow with NaH2PO2 as the phosphorus source [115]. Wang and coworkers reported a facile strategy to fabricate nickel-iron bimetallic phosphides nanorods from the NiFe2-MIL-88 precursor [116]. Firstly, NiFe2O4 nanorods were prepared by carbonization of NiFe2-MIL-88 at 450 °C under air. Then, NiFeP nanorods were obtained by phosphating the as-prepared NiFe2O4 nanorods at 400 °C under N2 flow with NaH2PO2 as the phosphorus source. The as-synthesized NiFeP remained the size and shape of the original NiFe2-MIL-88 precursor. Wang et al. synthesized Mo-CoP nanosheets by etching Co-MOF with sodium molybdate and subsequent phosphating reaction (Fig. 6 a) [117]. Red phosphorous can also act as a phosphorus source in gas-solid reaction, which produces white phosphorous gas under high temperatures and further react with MOF precursors. Chen and coworkers synthesized Co x P polyhedral particles via directly phosphating ZIF-67 with red phosphorous as the phosphorus source (Fig. 6b) [118]. In addition to the directly phosphating MOFs, phosphating their derived metals/metal oxides are also good choices to prepare TMPs. For instance, Xu and coworkers prepared the CoPS/N-doped carbon nanocomposites by pyrolyzing ZIF-67 into Co/N-C at 600 °C under N2 and subsequent further vacuum phosphosulfurization [119]. The other method is solid-state reaction. NaH2PO4 and Na2HPO4 are always employed as phosphorus sources [120]. Chen and coworkers reported an in-situ solid phase phosphating method to prepare porous CoP3 concave polyhedrons from ZIF-67 using NaH2PO4 and Na2HPO4 as the phosphorus sources [120]. At first, ZIF-67 was carbonized in air to prepare porous Co3O4. Subsequently, CoP3 was constructed by phosphating Co3O4. The serious drawback of external P sources is that they must be used in large quantities, and the molar ratio of metal to P is usually as high as 1:10–1:40, which will inevitably lead to the waste of a large amount of phosphorus resources and excessive emission of flammable and toxic PH3 gas. Therefore, the development of the metal-organic phosphine framework (MOPF) derivative strategy has attracted widespread interest. Organophosphine ligands in MOFs can also be employed as phosphorus sources in solid-state reaction (Fig. 6c and d) [121,122]. Without an additional P source, metal atoms can react with the P atoms in the organophosphine ligands to form TMPs. This strategy not only effectively reduces the intensive release of toxic PH3 gas and excessive waste of P resources, but also simplifies the synthesis process of TMPs. For example, Zhou and coworkers used a P-containing organic ligand (1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane, TPA) to fabricate Cu-based MOF for the preparation of carbon-confined Cu3P NPs (Fig. 6d) [122]. Firstly, Cu/PTA-MOPF was fabricated through mixing PTA and Cu(NO3)2 in a 1:1 molar ratio. In this process, PTA acted as a reducing agent to reduce Cu(II) to Cu(I) and could stabilize the low-oxidation metal state. On the other hand, part of PTA was protonated to form PTAH. Subsequently, Cu/PTA-MOPF was constructed through the self-assembly of Cu(I) and PTA/PTAH. Then, Cu3P/CNS was prepared via directly pyrolyzing Cu/PTA-MOPF at 500 °C under Ar without additional P sources. During the pyrolysis process, PTA provided P to react with Cu to form Cu3P. Precise control of the formation of P-containing species is also critical for the construction of highly active catalysts. Generally, controlling the synthesis conditions, such as the type of synthesis reaction, the type of metal and P source as well as their ratio, reaction temperature, and so on, can effectively control the formation of P species. Gas-solid reaction and solid-state reaction strategies are usually used to synthesize TMPs with relatively high temperature. However, the liquid-phase reaction strategy by lower temperature is often used to synthesize metal phosphates. For example, Ni-BTC (BTC = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) MOF was successfully converted into nickel phosphate by solvothermal method [123]. In addition, MOFs that contain P themselves will derive P-doped carbon while deriving TMPs. For instance, Cu/PTA-MOPF featured with P-contained ligand can be used to derive Cu3P NPs embedded in N, P co-doped carbon [122]. Moreover, phosphating different chemical states of the same metal can also construct TMPs with different crystal phases. Zou et al. constructed FeP and Fe2P through different treatments of Fe-MIL-88 precursors [124]. FeP was synthesized by first high-temperature pyrolysis of Fe-MIL-88 followed by low-temperature phosphating, while Fe2P could be obtained by directly phosphating Fe-MIL-88 under the same conditions. Furthermore, the different ratio of metal and P source can also lead to different crystal phases of TMPs. For instance, using red P as the P source and ZIF-67 as precursor, when the mass ratios of P/ZIF-67 were 0.3 and 0.5, CoP and Co2P could be obtained by directly phosphating at 700 °C, respectively [125,126]. Based on different phosphating processes, various types of catalysts may be synthesized, such as pure phase or heterogeneous TMPs, or composites of metals and TMPs. In order to confirm the structures of TMPs, careful characterizations are necessary. For instance, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) can be used to confirm the crystal structures of TMPs in the catalysts; X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) is usually used to confirm the electronic structure and local chemical environment of both metal and non-metal elements in TMPs; XPS can be used to verify the valence of their elements; scanning electron microscope (SEM) and TEM can reveal the microscopic morphology and/or crystal structures of the catalysts; Raman spectroscopy and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) are conducive to reveal the structural and bonding information [127,128]. 4 Strategies for improving the electrocatalytic performance of MOF-derived transition metal phosphides MOFs have significant advantages in composition adjustment and structural optimization. The coordination configurations, building blocks and ratios of metal ions in MOFs can be precisely adjusted at the atomic level [51,52]. Metal doping can promote the catalytic efficiency of electrocatalyst [129–132]. In addition, organic ligands can be modified to change the morphology and structure of MOFs. Moreover, organic ligands can be converted to graphitic carbon or amorphous carbon during the pyrolysis process [70,71,133]. These carbon layers can improve the conductivity of metal phosphide NPs as well as prevent them from agglomerating and effectively reduce the etching from strong acidic and alkaline electrolytes, thereby improving their activity and stability. Furthermore, pyrolysis of MOFs with heteroatom-containing ligands (N, S, P) can insert N, P or S atoms into the carbon matrix to provide more active sites as well as modulate their electronic structures [121,122]. Therefore, the catalytic performances of MOF-derived TMPs can be tuned through the strategies of component regulation (metal regulation and ligand regulation) and morphology regulation. 4.1 Component regulation 4.1.1 Metal regulation Some studies have shown that the electronic structure and atomic coordination of TMPs can be significantly adjusted when other metals were incorporated, thereby adjusting their catalytic performance [132,134]. The incorporation of heteroatoms enables to regulate the electronic configuration of the metal centers and regulate their electronic interactions with key reaction intermediates, thereby improving the catalytic activity. It is mainly reflected in the microscopic alterations in the electronic band structure of the catalysts and the local charge distribution at the active sites [129,130]. Firstly, heteroatoms can replace the host atoms in the crystal lattice, and introduce excess electrons or holes, change the electronic ribbon configuration of the catalysts, and optimize the electron transports during reaction. Secondly, the electronic interaction between the doped guest heteroatoms and the host atoms can change the local charge distribution of the active sites, thereby regulating the adsorption and activation of the reaction intermediates. For example, the doped guest Ni atom can transfer electrons to the host Co atom, increasing the electron density around the host atom to facilitate HER [134]. MOFs show many advantages in metal regulation. For example, the metal nodes of MOFs are highly adjustable, which can easily replace various types of metals and precisely adjust the metal ratio. The metal centers in MOFs are dispersed at the atomic level, which can precisely control the doping degree and uniformity of the metals. For HER, it is also a good way to evaluate the efficiency of electrocatalysts via the hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔG H) [132]. The binding strength of the catalyst to the intermediate should not be overly weak or strong. Although the strong binding force is favorable for absorbing H* and promoting the transfer of electrons to protons, it is not conducive to the removal of adsorbed H* as well as the generation of H2. The ideal value of ΔG H is zero, indicating an optimized bonding strength, meaning that the catalysts have excellent catalytic activity [132]. Incorporating additional metals into the lattices of TMPs optimizes the ΔG H, thus balancing proton transfer and hydrogen release [134]. In addition to ΔG H, the kinetic barrier to water dissociation sometimes affects the entire HER process and is another key factor that reflects catalytic activity, especially those happened in alkaline conditions [134]. Metal doping can effectively reduce kinetic barriers to water dissociation through hetero-metal synergistic effects. For example, Li et al. utilized metal precursor@ZIF-67 as templates to derive M−doped CoP (M = Ni, Mn, Fe) electrocatalysts (Fig. 7 a) [134]. The measurements showed that M−CoP had better HER activity than CoP without metal doping. In particular, Ni doped CoP exhibited the best catalytic performance and needed overpotentials of 92 and 144 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4, respectively (Fig. 7e and f). They combined a series of characterizations and DFT calculations to uncover the essential reason for the enhanced activity (Fig. 7b–d). The results indicated that the ΔG H could be optimized and the downshift of d-band center could further reduce H bonding strength after metal doping, thus promoting catalytic kinetic for HER. Several studies have previously shown that the driving energy of the OER intermediates (OH*, O*, and OOH*) of electrocatalysts determined their OER performance [135–137]. Therefore, the free energy of each basic step can reflect the OER kinetics of the catalyst. Especially, the rate-determining step (RDS) of metal-oxides/hydroxide catalysts is usually the formation of OOH*, showing the highest free energy change. Compared to catalysts without introducing metal, the binding energy of the intermediate of the catalyst after metal doping decreased [135–137]. For instance, Yu and coworkers constructed a series of bimetal phosphide nanosheets by phosphating MOF nanosheets (MOFNs) and studied the OER activity of these metal-doped cobalt-based phosphide nanosheets (CoM-P-NS) [135]. Compared to the cobalt phosphide, these derived CoM-P-NS exhibited fabulous OER efficiency. In particular, the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 for the optimized CoNi-P-NS was only 273 mV in alkaline media. The theoretical studies had shown that the OER intermediates' binding energy of CoNi-P-O after Ni doping decreased compared with Co-P-O without Ni doping. Therefore, CoNi-P electrocatalyst could significantly reduce the activation barrier with respect to single metal phosphide. Peng et al. regulated the structure and morphology of Ni2P via introducing Fe to improve the catalytic performance (Fig. 7g) [136]. The electrocatalytic efficiency of Fe-Ni2P was dramatically increased after adding an appropriate amount of iron (Fig. 7k and l). The cell potential for Fe-Ni2P at 100 mA cm−2 was only 1.57 V. DFT calculations were used to investigate the nature of Fe doping to enhance catalyst activity. (Fig. 7h–j). For HER, they found that little iron incorporation could significantly decrease ΔG H, which facilitated the kinetics of hydrogen conversion. For OER, compared with Ni2P, Fe doped Ni2P had a lower energy barrier in the RDS. Fe doping could significantly tune the binding energy of the intermediate to an optimal value, thus increasing the energetics for OER. Wang and coworkers took advantage of a Co-MOF to fabricate Mo-doped CoP and studied the effect of Mo doping on both HER and OER activities of CoP [137]. The overpotentials for Mo-doped CoP at 10 mA cm−2 were 305 and 44 mV for OER and HER. DFT calculations revealed that Mo doping was beneficial for the reduction of ΔG H, which considerably strengthened the HER efficiency. In addition, Mo lowered the strength of the H–O bond in OH*, which was conducive to limiting the potential deprotonation process and boosting OER activity. Overall, the uniform doping of metal can effectively adjust the electronic structure, thereby optimizing the ΔG H of the HER and the binding energy of the OER intermediates. 4.1.2 Ligand regulation Compared with metal regulation, ligand regulation seems a more flexible and effective strategy. The highly adjustable and abundant organic ligands in MOFs can not only directionally regulate the morphology and pore characteristics of MOF precursors, but also significantly reduce the diffusion and agglomeration of metal species during the pyrolysis process by their coordination confinement effect, thus facilitating the construction of ultrafine TMP nanostructure. Besides, the organic ligands can be in-situ transformed into robust carbon layers, which can be used as electronic regulators and structural stabilizers for the TMPs. The rich organic components of MOFs will be converted into carbon during carbonization. Precisely regulating the ligands can optimize the derived carbon substrates, thus optimizing the electrocatalytic property. In general, organic ligands are highly modifiable (Fig. 8 ). Reasonable designing MOFs with heteroatom (N, P or S) incorporated in the ligands as precursors can avoid mechanical mixing in the synthesis, thereby achieving uniform doping of the elements in the catalysts [121,122]. On one hand, because the nano-scale TMP particles have a higher surface energy and tend to aggregate during the electrocatalysis process, the derived heteroatom-doped carbon layer can protect the active species from agglomeration. On the other hand, synergistic catalysis between TMPs and heteroatom-doped carbon can further promote the electrocatalytic property of catalysts. Some studies have reported the regulation of HER activity by N-doped carbon [138–140]. Due to the difference in electronegativity, N atom doping will cause asymmetric charge distribution on adjacent carbon atoms and result in greater polarization, which will lead to stronger affinity for H atoms [138]. In addition, N can exchange electrons with the encapsulated TMPs, thereby tuning the affinities to the reaction intermediates and then regulating the catalytic performances [140]. For example, Luo et al. utilized ZIF-9 to prepare N-doped carbon-coated CoP NPs (CoP@NC) [141]. The derived CoP@NC catalyst showed great electrocatalytic performance and durability. The needed overpotential for CoP@NC was 78 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in acidic media, which was notably superior to CoP@C (without N doping) and CoP. DFT calculations proved that the cooperative catalysis among CoP and the NC layer was essentially responsible for the elevated electrochemical HER efficiency. The HER properties of metal phosphides can be further improved by co-doping N with other heteroatoms (such as S or P). Generality, increasing the number of doped heteroatoms in the carbon layer and the electronic interactions between different doped heteroatoms usually promotes the HER catalytic process [142–144]. Yan et al. fabricated S, N co-doped carbon-coated S-doped CoWP NPs (S-CoWP@(S,N)-C) from a CoW-based MOF (Fig. 9 a), which contained high contents of N and S [143]. Their derived electrocatalyst was doped with S in both the CoWP core and the carbon shell, and N was also co-doped into the carbon shell (Fig. 9a). For HER, the afforded overpotentials for S-CoWP@(S,N)-C at 10 mA cm−2 were 67 mV (1.0 M KOH) and 35 mV (0.5 M H2SO4). DFT calculations illustrated that N-doping was better than S-doping for reducing ΔG H, because N-doping could strengthen the electrical conductivity of carbon and generated or adjusted the electron donor-acceptor behavior, so it is favorable for catalytic activity. Xiang et al. used MIL-101-NH2-Fe-P as a precursor to fabricate N, P co-doped carbon incorporated iron phosphide (Fig. 9b) [144]. The MOF precursor provided P and N sources, and was also used as a nano-scale confined space under pyrolysis. The derived porous carbon can reduce the agglomeration of NPs, so the prepared FeP x NPs (20–100 nm) were highly dispersed in the carbon substrate. The Fe x P@NPC electrocatalyst showed great electrochemical performance and excellent stability for HER in acidic media. They revealed that because phosphorus had greater electronegativity than transition metals, it not only acted as a proton acceptor, but also weakened the adsorption strength of Fe to H or other intermediates. Studies have shown that heteroatom-doped carbons can be used as a kind of metal-free OER electrocatalysts [145–148]. Heteroatom-doped carbons can not only provide additional catalytic sites, but also the co-catalysis with TMPs can boost the electrocatalytic activity of electrocatalysts for OER [148]. Zeng and coworkers fabricated carbon incorporated bimetal phosphide (NiFeP x @NPS-C) from a MOF-based precursor without any extra P and dopant sources (Fig. 9c) [149]. The overpotential for NiFeP x @NPS-C at 10 mA cm−2 for OER was 265 mV. The great electrochemical property was ascribed to the interaction of the wrapped NiFeP x NPs with the carbon matrix. Thomas et al. used bipyridine and phosphonate linked Ni MOF as a precursor to fabricate N, P-doped carbon incorporated Ni2P nanocrystals (Ni2P-NPCM) [150]. They confirmed that due to the doping of nitrogen and phosphorus into the carbon layer, there would be more active site defects in the catalyst, resulting in increased catalytic efficiency. The cell potential for Ni2P-NPCM at 10 mA cm−2 was 1.62 V. The in-situ generated carbon layer can effectively enhance the electrocatalytic stability of TMPs. On one hand, the confinement effect of the carbon layer can effectively reduce the agglomeration of TMPs NPs during the synthesis and catalysis. On the other hand, the encapsulated carbon layer can slow down the etching of TMPs by strong acidic and basic electrolytes. Nevertheless, the problem of oxidative corrosion of carbon during the OER process should not be neglected [151,152]. Carbon carriers are susceptible to oxidative corrosion at high oxidation potentials. Therefore, many studies have reported strategies to mitigate carbon corrosion, such as increasing the graphitization of carbon and doping the carbon substrate with monodisperse Mn sites [153,154]. Despite the corrosion problem of carbon at oxidation potential, the special combination of carbon carriers with TMPs NPs makes these composite materials suitable for electrolysis of water. Moreover, the system with TMPs loaded on carbon supports has the prospect of sustainable development since the carbon materials are diverse and abundant. Furthermore, the carbon layer also makes an important contribution to the improvement of catalytic activity [155,156], especially that combined with trace metals can serve as effectively active sites for HER or OER. For instance, Heumann et al. revealed the microscopic alterations of carbon surface in OER, elucidating that particular oxygen species on the carbon surface could promote OER activity [157]. These oxidized functional groups could adsorb iron impurities in solution to in-situ form C-O-Fe, which could not only serve as the intrinsic active sites, but also slow down the deep oxidation of the carbon surface. In a word, the carbon layers can also be positive for improving the stability and activity of TMP-based electrocatalysts. 4.2 Morphology regulation MOF materials with various morphologies can be fabricated through the reaction of metal centers and ligands under different synthesized conditions [53]. Therefore, it provided a useable way to modulate the morphologies of TMPs through the MOF-templates. Modulating the morphologies of catalysts to increase the specific surface areas and catalytic centers is beneficial to improve the catalytic activity. There are several methods for controlling the morphologies of the MOF precursors. The key to constructing 0D MOFs with uniform shape is to enable rapid nucleation and restrict crystal size, generally including coordination modulation strategy and microemulsion method. The coordination regulation strategy is to use non-bridging coordination regulators to contest the organic ligands for coordination, thereby regulating the sizes of MOFs [158]. The type and concentration of the modifier affect the size and uniformity of MOFs. Fischer et al. constructed a small-sized MOF-5 (<100 nm) employing p-perfluoro-methylbenzoic acid as a regulator [159]. In addition, some surfactants or polymers can also decelerate the growth of MOFs. Johnson et al. constructed small-sized MOF-5 (ca. 30 nm) and UiO-66 (ca. 36 nm) NPs with the modulation of ligands containing poly(ethylene glycol) [160]. Microemulsions are composed of immiscible solvents and emulsifiers, which can control the nucleation of MOF particles, thereby constructing 0D MOFs with good dispersibility and uniform size [161]. For example, Lin et al. successfully fabricated 0D HKUST-1 nanospheres (diameter: ca. 30 nm) with uniform morphology utilizing the microemulsion method [162]. The fabrication of 1D MOF nanostructures can be achieved through template approach [163]. Template method is a great approach for fabricating MOFs with controllable morphology and size. Templates commonly used to prepare 1D MOFs include Te nanowires, cellulose, ZnO nanorods, polystyrene-poly-4-vinylpyridine copolymers, track-etched polycarbonate (PCTE) membrane, and so on [163,164]. For example, using PCTE membrane as the template, 1D ZIF-8 nanowires, nanotubes, and nanorods could be prepared [164]. Top-down and bottom-up strategies are frequently used to construct 2D MOF nanosheets [165–167]. Many MOFs with a layered structure are combined by weak interaction between planes such as hydrogen bonding and van der Waals forces. The top-down approaches such as physical exfoliation and chemical exfoliation can overcome the planar force in these inherent layered MOFs, thereby preparing 2D MOF nanosheets [165]. For example, through ultrasonic treatment in DMF solution, the bulk MOF (Zn4O(L)3, L = 2,5-bis(3-methoxypropoxy)-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) was peeled into ultrathin MOF nanosheets [168]. The essential reason was that the weak coordination between the side chain of L and Zn2+ was easily destroyed by DMF molecules under the assistance of ultrasound. Yang et al. used the ball milling and ultrasonic exfoliation approaches to process bulk Zn2(benzimidazole)4 to prepare ultrathin MOF nanosheets (1.0 nm) (Fig. 10 a and b) [169]. Chemical exfoliation is also an ideal method for constructing 2D MOF nanosheets. Compared to physical exfoliation, chemical exfoliation successfully overcomes the difficulty of uncontrollable size and thickness. Jiang et al. inserted 4,4′-dipyridyl disulfide into the layered porphyrinic MOF (Fig. 10c) [170]. Then, breaking the disulfide bond could produce ultrathin MOF nanosheets. By controlling the degree of reduction of the disulfide bonds in the disulfide ligands, MOF nanosheets with different thicknesses could be further obtained. The bottom-up approach constructs 2D MOF nanosheets through coordination of ligands with metal centers, which is beneficial to manage the growth of MOF nanosheets [165]. Precise control of the growing rate of MOFs in a specific orientation is the essence of the approach. The bottom-up strategy includes interface growth method, surfactant assisted method, template assisted method and so on [165]. The interface growth method is the coordination of ligands with metal centers in distinct phases at the interface to form MOFs. The key of this method is to fabricate a suitable interface with adaptive molecular or ion diffusion capabilities and enough reaction area. For instance, Gascon et al. synthesized a Cu-based 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (Cu-BDC) MOF using the interface growth method [171]. Laying the metal ion layer on the organic ligand layer, Cu2+ and BDC ligand would slowly diffuse into the intermediate solution layer, forming MOF nanosheets on the interface. The intermediate layer offered an enough reaction zone for the generation of 2D MOF. The newly generated 2D Cu-BDC was naturally removed from the reaction zone through precipitation, and thereafter further inhibited the growth of Cu-BDC in the organic ligand phase lacking Cu2+ ions. The surfactant assisted method is to select suitable surfactants to selectively attach to a specific crystal face of the MOF crystal to inhibit the growth of the crystal on the crystal face to construct 2D MOF nanosheets. Commonly used surfactants for controlling the synthesis of MOF nanosheets are cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), and sodium lauryl sulfate (SLS), etc. Zhang et al. fabricated M-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (TCPP) MOF nanosheets via the PVP-assisted synthetic approach (Fig. 10d) [172]. PVP might coordinate with the metal ions and prevent the interaction between M-TCPP nanosheets, thereby obtaining 2D MOF nanosheets. By rationally designing MOFs and further treatments, various morphologies of TMPs can be fabricated. The 3D MOFs here refer to MOFs with hollow structures or other special morphologies. The strategies of constructing hollow 3D MOFs commonly include etching method and template method. The etching method is usually post-treatment of MOFs with chemical reagents to form hollow structures. Since the interior of MOFs has more defects than the periphery, their internals can be more easily etched to form hollow structures [173]. Huo et al. constructed a hollow Cr-MIL-101 using acetic acid as an etching reagent [174]. The template method is also an effective strategy for constructing hollow MOFs, which usually includes the following three steps: constructing the template, in-situ growing the MOF around the template, and finally removing the template. Commonly used templates are polymers, metals, SiO2, etc. with a certain morphology. For instance, Oh et al. constructed hollow ZIF-8 using polystyrene (PS) spheres as a template [175]. 4.2.1 MOF-derived zero-dimensional transition metal phosphides The insertion of in-situ generated carbon during the pyrolysis of MOFs can not only limit the growth of NPs and thus prepare ultrafine TMP NPs, but also avoid their agglomeration. Therefore, MOF-derived metal phosphide NPs usually exhibit excellent electrochemical activity and stability [176–180]. Mai et al. grew needle-like Ni-MOF on reduced graphene oxide (Ni-MOF/rGO) via a solvothermal method, and then carbonized and phosphatized Ni-MOF/rGO under argon atmosphere to synthesize carbon coated Ni2P nanocrystals (Fig. 11 a) [179]. The size of the obtained Ni2P nanocrystals was about 13 nm, which was wrapped by ultrathin carbon layers and evenly distributed in the graphene layer without agglomeration. The overpotential for the electrocatalyst at 10 mA cm−2 for OER was 285 mV. The smaller the size of metal phosphide NPs can present more catalytic centers, thus exhibiting enhanced electrocatalytic performance. Wang et al. prepared 2D Co-Fe MOF nanosheets using the interface growth method, and then ultrafine Co0.7Fe0.3P NPs were prepared by low-temperature phosphating (Fig. 11b) [180]. Benefiting from the fact that the 2D precursor could limit the growth of Co0.7Fe0.3P NPs during the phosphating process, the derived Co0.7Fe0.3P NPs had a particle size of less than 5 nm and were evenly dispersed in the 2D carbon layer. The overpotential for Co0.7Fe0.3P at 10 mA cm−2 for OER was only 270 mV. 4.2.2 MOF-derived one-dimensional transition metal phosphides Zhao et al. prepared Ni-Co phosphide nanotubes by calcining and phosphating solid bimetallic MOF-74 nanorods (Fig. 11c) [181]. The nanotubes supplied plentiful catalytic sites and stimulated adequate exposure to the electrolytes. The derived Ni-Co phosphide nanotubes showed remarkable electrocatalytic reactivity. In particular, the cell voltage for CoNiP at 10 mA cm−2 was 1.59 V. Yin et al. constructed needle-like Co(OH)F on carbon fiber paper (CFP), and applied it as a template to react with imidazole vapor to synthesize Co-MOF nanorods, and finally synthesized CoP/Co-MOF nanorods hybrid materials by phosphating part of Co-MOF (Fig. 11d) [182]. The afforded overpotentials for CoP/Co-MOF at 10 mA cm−2 were 34 and 27 mV in 1.0 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4. The upgraded catalytic efficiency for HER could be ascribed to the porous nanorod structure facilitating gas release and exposing rich active sites, as well as the synergy between CoP and Co-MOF. 4.2.3 MOF-derived two-dimensional transition metal phosphides Du et al. reported MOF derived porous Ni2P nanosheets for HER and OER [183]. Firstly, NiO nanosheets were synthesized and employed as templates to react with 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid ligand to construct MOF-74. Finally, porous Ni2P nanosheets were prepared by phosphating MOF-74. The cell potential for Ni2P at 10 mA cm−2 was 1.52 V. Liao et al. constructed 2D MOF nanosheets through a solvothermal reaction, then prepared metal phosphide nanosheets by low-temperature phosphating MOFs (Fig. 11e) [184]. Due to the ultra-thin nanosheet structure, the derived cobalt-based homometallic phosphide showed a low overpotential of 292 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for OER. Qi et al. prepared Zn and Fe doped CoP core-shell nanosheets from an Fe-doped ZnCo MOF for overall water splitting (Fig. 11f) [185]. Firstly, ZnCo MOF nanoarrays were fabricated on carbon cloth (CC) through a gentle coprecipitation method. Then, Fe/Zn-Co3O4 nanosheets were constructed through the exchange and etching of Fe2+ and subsequent carbonization. Finally, Zn and Fe co-doped CoP nanosheets were prepared by phosphating Fe/Zn-Co3O4. The cell potential for Zn/Fe-CoP at 10 mA cm−2 was merely 1.59 V. 4.2.4 MOF-derived hollow structured transition metal phosphides The hollow structured catalysts have an extremely high utilization of both the external and internal spaces, thus exposing a wealth of catalytic active sites [186]. MOFs can be easily designed as different geometrical shapes and derived into hollow structured TMPs, which served as efficient ways to modulate the active structures and regions of TMPs for enhanced electrocatalytic performance [187–195]. Tong et al. utilized dopamine as an etching agent to etch ZIF-67 nanocubes to prepare metal-dopamine hollow nanocubes, followed by pyrolysis and phosphating the metal- dopamine to prepare hollow-structured Co/Co2P catalysts (Fig. 11g) [194]. Co/Co2P was not only introduced into N-doped amorphous carbon hollow nanocubes, but also formed the interface with CNTs which were derived from the in-situ conversion of organic ligands during the pyrolysis process. The synergistic effect between Co/Co2P and CNTs could increase the catalytic sites and reduce ΔG H. Therefore, Co/Co2P@CNTs presented superb electrocatalytic HER efficiency. Dong et al. reported on MOF-derived nickel-cobalt phosphide polyhedral nanocages for OER (Fig. 11h) [195]. Firstly, NiCo-ZIF was synthesized via a co-precipitation approach. Subsequently, NiCo-ZIF polyhedra was etched using tannic acid as an etching agent to prepare NiCo polyhedral nanocages with hollow structure. Finally, NiCoP/NC hollow nanocages were constructed through carbonization and phosphating treatment, which showed abundant pore volume and large surface areas. The overpotential of NiCoP/NC at 10 mA cm−2 for OER was 297 mV in 1.0 M KOH. 5 MOF-derived transition metal phosphides for electrocatalytic water splitting TMPs derived from MOFs can perfectly preserve the initial architectural features of MOFs, demonstrating homogeneous catalytic active sites and large specific surface areas. In general, the electrical conductivity and stability of TMPs can be significantly improved thanks to the in-situ formation of carbon layers. Therefore, these TMP-based electrocatalysts exhibited remarkable electrocatalytic efficiency. At present, the application of MOF-derived TMPs in water electrolysis has been widely reported. Tables 2–4 presented the electrochemical properties of TMP-based electrocatalysts from MOFs for water splitting. 5.1 MOF-derived transition metal phosphides for HER 5.1.1 MOF-derived single metal phosphides The single metal (Ni, Co, Fe, Cu, Mo etc.) phosphides derived from MOFs exhibit great catalytic efficiency for HER [196–207]. For instance, Zhao et al. developed a highly active Ni2P catalyst for HER by directly phosphating MOF-74-Ni [208]. The as-prepared Ni2P well preserved the high porosity and shape of MOF-74-Ni, showing high dispersibility and exposing abundant catalytic sites. The overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 and Tafel slope for the Ni2P electrocatalyst were 158 mV and 73 mVdec−1 in acidic media. Moreover, Ni2P displayed glorious long-term tolerance in solutions of varying pH. Wang et al. prepared the CoP/C nanoboxes for HER through carbonizing phytic acid (PA) cross-linked ZIF-67 (Fig. 12 a) [209]. They found that PA could not only slowly etch ZIF-67 to fabricate a hollow structure, but also could be used as the P source to synthesize CoP electrocatalyst. Because PA had six phosphate groups, it could etch ZIF-67 by releasing hydrogen ions to form a hollow structure, and the amount of PA added was key to the construction of structurally unique Co-PA nanoboxes. Under reducing conditions, the P–O bond in the PA phosphate group was broken, and the released P reacted with Co to generate CoP catalyst, while other organic species converted into the carbon carrier. Thanks to the novel hollow architecture, CoP/C displayed great catalytic efficiency in acidic solution (Fig. 12b and c). Zou et al. utilized an iron-based triazolate-containing MOF (MET(Fe)) as a precursor to prepare iron phosphide for HER [210]. The derived FeP catalyst had a hierarchically porous nano-bundle structure, providing abundant channels and high specific surface areas, facilitating the exposure of abundant catalytic sites and the release of H2. After mixing super P with FeP-500, the as-prepared FeP-500-S delivered great HER performance (η 10 = 165 mV). Zang et al. fabricated carbon coated Cu3P NPs (Cu3P@NPPC) by pyrolyzing Cu-based MOF, which was formed by connecting divalent copper ion with N-containing pyrazine and P-containing 1-hydroxyethylidene-1,1-diphosphonic acid (Fig. 12d) [211]. The 3D Cu-MOF structure containing N, P heteroatoms enabled the N and P active sites to be uniformly incorporated into the graphite carbon layer and promoted the homogenous dispersion of copper NPs in the N, P co-doped carbon layer. And the construction of MOF-derived TMPs was affected by the pyrolysis temperature. Heat treatment at different temperatures would result in different degrees of carbonization, affecting the porosity and electrical conductivity of the electrocatalyst. In 0.5 M H2SO4, Cu3P@NPPC only demanded an overpotential of 89 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER (Fig. 12e–h). The cooperative interaction between Cu3P and carbon substrate was the essential reason for the excellent electrochemical activity. Li et al. invented MoP NPs uniformly distributed in porous carbon for HER by a MOF-assisted strategy (Fig. 12i) [212]. They chose UIO-66 as the host, which was constructed by self-assembly of Zr6O4(OH)4(CO2)12 and 1,4-dicarboxybenzene. These ultrafine nanopores in UiO-66 (0.6 nm) were able to capture the vaporized MoO3 under the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) condition. Subsequently, the adsorbed MoO3 was reduced through a corresponding limited carburizing reaction, thereby generating small MoO2 nanocrystals. At last, MoO2 NPs were converted to MoP through PH3, generating in-situ from the decomposition of (NH4)2HPO4. The cooperative interaction between MoP NPs and in-situ generated carbon endowed the catalyst with outstanding catalytic efficiency. In 0.5 M H2SO4, MoP@PC required an overpotential of 153 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER, exhibiting great conductivity and stability (Fig. 12g–m). 5.1.2 MOF-derived binary metal phosphides Doping additional metal elements into TMPs can significantly tune the coordination environment and electronic structure, thereby adjusting their catalytic efficiency. Therefore, MOF-derived binary metal phosphides showed outstanding electrochemical performance [213–216]. Sun and coworkers constructed a Co-doped FeP catalyst (called Co-Fe-P) with a nanotube structure from MIL-88B [217]. Two metal salts and 1,4-phthalic acid were self-assembled into CoFe-MIL-88B nanorods under solvothermal conditions. Then, the CoFe-MIL-88B nanorods were calcined in air to be converted into a mixed metal oxide (CoFeO x ) having a hollow structure. Finally, Co-Fe-P nanotubes with uniformly distributed Co, Fe and P atoms were fabricated via phosphating. The as-prepared Co-Fe-P nanotubes showed excellent catalytic performance for HER. In addition, Co-Fe-P nanotubes also exhibited high stability during electrocatalysis. They revealed that the atomic-level electronic structure regulation and the desired tubular morphology could promote catalytic capability. DFT calculations illustrated that the incorporation of Co enhanced the total density of states (DOS) adjacent to the Fermi level, which could enhance the catalytic performance. The unique nanotube structure and the cooperative coupling effect caused by Co substitution endowed Co-Fe-P with short mass diffusion way, abundant catalytically active sites, high conductivity, and desirable electronic configuration. Li et al. synthesized a nitrogen/phosphorus co-doped carbon coated iron phosphide/molybdenum phosphide electrocatalyst (FeP/MoP@NPC) for HER using a mixture of polyorganometalate-based MOF (PMo12@MIL-100) and melamine as a precursor [218]. Melamine not only provided the C and N sources, but also promoted the generation of N, P co-doped carbon to coat FeP/MoP NPs. The derived carbon layer could not only boost the charge transfer, but also prevent the FeP/MoP center from being corroded, thereby enhancing the stability. In addition, the introduction of heteroatoms (N, P) was conducive to the creation of more active sites. Therefore, the FeP/MoP@NPC electrocatalyst exhibited highly efficient activity for electrocatalytic HER. 5.2 MOF-derived transition metal phosphides for OER Benefiting from the highly dispersed catalytic sites and the protection of the in-situ formed carbon layers, MOF-derived TMPs also showed remarkable electrochemical activity and stability for OER [125,219–236]. Lou et al. fabricated a carbon-inserted Ni-Co phosphide (NiCoP/C) for OER from ZIF-67 (Fig. 13 a) [237]. Firstly, ZIF-67 with a nanocube morphology was constructed. SEM and TEM showed that the prepared nanocubes had a solid structure. Subsequently, further interaction of Ni(NO3)2 with ZIF-67 in aqueous solution could promote the conversion of solid ZIF-67 nanocubes into hollow nanoboxes and fabricate Ni-Co LDH on ZIF-67. Finally, NiCoP/C was obtained through phosphating the as-prepared ZIF-67@LDH nanoboxes at 350 °C under N2 flow with NaH2PO2 as the phosphorus source. The as-synthesized NiCoP/C remained the shape of a hollow nanobox, but the nanosheets on the surface had become NPs. Thanks to the advantages of well-defined composition and structure, the overpotential for NiCoP/C at 10 mA cm−2 was 330 mV (Fig. 13b and c). Zhu et al. utilized an Fe-Co MOF to produce iron-cobalt phosphide (Fe-Co-P) with a hollow structure and good conductivity for OER (Fig. 13d) [238]. Firstly, under solvothermal conditions, two metal salts and trimesic acid were self-assembled into Fe-Co MOF hollow spheres. Then, Fe-Co MOF was calcined in Ar to be converted into a mixed metal oxide. Finally, the Co-Fe-P catalyst was fabricated via phosphating the as-synthesized Co-Fe oxide hollow spheres. Co-Fe-P displayed supreme OER property (η 10 = 252 mV) (Fig. 13e). Co-Fe-P also exhibited a very low Tafel slope of only 33 mV dec−1 (Fig. 13f). DFT calculations confirmed that adding high-valent iron could stabilize cobalt at a low price, resulting in an increase in catalytic efficiency. Besides, the rich catalytic sites and the increased conductivity after carbon insertion could further enhance the electrochemical activity for OER. Huang et al. synthesized a carbon-encapsulated bimetal phosphide (FeNiP/C) from a bimetal MOF [239]. As shown in Fig. 13(g), the P-containing BMM-10 was constructed by self-assembling a divalent nickel salts with 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]-octane and tris-(4-carboxylphenyl) phosphine oxide. Then, BMM-10 was etched to form Fe-Ni-HNP by an acidic solution produced from Fe(NO3)3. Finally, Fe-Ni-HNP was transformed to FeNiP/C through heat treatment without other P sources. In addition, a high calcination temperature was conducive to reducing metal atoms and dissociating the P–O and C–P bonds in the precursor, thereby helping to form FeNiP NPs. The in-situ generated conductive graphite carbon firmly covered the FeNiP NPs, which could strengthen the electrochemical efficiency for OER. The derived FeNiP/C-900 showed an overpotential of 229 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH (Fig. 13h). FeNiP/C-900 also exhibited a Tafel slope of 74.5 mV dec−1 (Fig. 13i). MOF-derived ternary metal phosphides offer more possibilities for electronic regulation and therefore exhibit outstanding catalytic activity for OER [240,241]. Shen et al. precisely adjusted the ratio of Ni and Fe in ZIF-67, and then synthesized a ternary metal phosphide with a hollow structure through the high-temperature reduction and phosphating reactions [240]. The as-obtained CoNi0.2Fe0.05-P showed good OER activity. They demonstrated that the (hydroxy)oxide/phosphate species formed by the oxidation of the phosphide surface during the electrochemical process was the essential cause of the enhanced OER performance, because this structure maintained the excellent electron transfer capability of the phosphide and added a wealth of catalytic active sites. In addition, the simultaneous doping of nickel and iron could significantly regulate the electronic structure of the metal phosphide, leading to an effective reduction of the energy barrier in the reaction and thus further improving the electrocatalytic performance for OER. Jia et al. prepared ternary metal phosphide (P-CoNiFe) by a solvothermal method and subsequent low-temperature phosphating method [241]. P-CoNiFe showed porous layered hollow spherical morphology. They confirmed that the solvothermal method might be an effective strategy for converting MOF into hollow spheres assembled from 2D hydroxide nanosheets. Firstly, they constructed CoNi-ZIF via the ultrasound approach. Then, the precursor was re-dispersed in a methanol solution and mixed with Co, Ni, and Fe salts. After solvent heat treatment, the precursor was converted into a hollow spherical structure intermediate. Finally, P-CoNiFe was prepared by low-temperature phosphating of the intermediate. The 2D structured nanosheets constituting the hollow spheres had ultra-thin thickness and large lateral dimensions, which would facilitate charge transfer, mass transfer, and contact with the electrolyte. In particular, the catalytic sites' electronic configuration could be effectively tuned when inserting multi-metal elements, boosting both the electrocatalytic performance and the electrical conductivity. 5.3 MOF-derived transition metal phosphides for overall water splitting Using the same catalyst to effectively drive the total water decomposition not only simplifies the preparation steps but also decreases production expenses, so MOF-derived TMPs for overall water splitting have attracted much attention [124,126,242–255]. Lin and coworkers used copper-doped ZIF-67 as a precursor to construct a bimetal phosphide for both HER and OER [256]. Firstly, two metal salts and 2-methylimidazole were self-assembled into bimetal ZIF. The as-prepared bimetal ZIF precursor was then carbonized and phosphorylated to obtain the final electrocatalyst (Fig. 14 a). By adjusting the ratio of Cu and Co, the electrochemical capability of the derived bimetal phosphide was optimized. Among them, the employed cell potential for Cu0.3Co2.7P/NC at 70 mA cm−2 was only 1.74 V, showing long-term tolerance (Fig. 14b and c). DFT calculations confirmed that less electron accumulations and covalently bonded elements were found around the inserted copper atoms, which was conducive to enhancing electrical conductivity. In addition, Cu doping also optimized the adsorption energy of hydrogen, thereby promoting the adsorption and desorption of hydrogen. Baek et al. synthesized Fe-doped CoP for HER and OER through phosphating Co-Fe MOF [257]. After Fe doping, due to its different electronegativity, the adsorption of catalytic reaction intermediates could be adjusted, thereby enhancing the dissociation of H2O and OH. Co0.68Fe0.32P exhibited prominent catalytic efficiency (HER: η 10 = 116 mV, OER: η 10 = 289 mV). In addition to regulating the electronic configuration through introducing metal to stimulate the inherent reactivity of the active sites, strategies such as modulating the morphology of the MOF precursors, inserting carbon materials, and constructing self-supporting electrodes can further elevate the electronic conductivity, the specific surface area, electrochemical catalytic sites of the catalyst, thereby increasing the catalytic activity. 5.3.1 MOF precursor morphology regulation In addition to changing organic ligands to regulate the morphology of MOFs, the morphology of MOFs can often be regulated via changing the synthesis conditions or post-processing MOFs [258–267]. MOF-derived low-dimensional phosphides (nanosheets, nanowires, nanoroads, etc.) generally have better electrical conductivity as well as highly exposed catalytic centers. For example, Wang et al. fabricated the ZIF-67 nanoplates by changing the synthesis conditions, and then carbonizing and subsequent phosphating to obtain 2D porous cobalt phosphide nanosheets (CoPO) for electrocatalytic overall water splitting (Fig. 14d) [268]. Firstly, the cobalt salts and 2-methylimidazole were self-assembled into 2D ZIF-67 stacked nanoplates by solvothermal reaction. Subsequently, cobalt oxide nanosheets were obtained through heat treating ZIF-67 nanoplates in air. At last, P and O were co-doped into the nanosheets by phosphating. They revealed that the solvothermal treatment was key to fabricating 2D ZIF-67 nanoplates. The thickness of the as-synthesized 2D ultrathin porous CoPO nanosheet was about 5.2 nm. CoPO exhibited outstanding catalytic performance with a cell potential of 1.52 V at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 14e). The ultrathin porous nanosheet structure could expose a wealth of catalytic active sites, which was the essential reason for its high efficiency. Post-treatment of MOFs is also an effective strategy for preparing low-dimensional metal phosphides [269,270]. Li et al. utilized manganese salts etching ZIF-67 to prepare MnCo2O4 nanosheets, and then synthesized Mn-doped CoP porous nanosheets (Mn-CoP) by carbonization and phosphating [269]. Thanks to the abundance of highly exposed catalytic sites provided by the nanosheet architecture, Mn-CoP displayed impressive catalytic performance (HER: η 10 = 195 mV, OER: η 10 = 290 mV). Li et al. synthesized CoP NPs inserted carbon substrate with hollow structure (NCNHP) by post-processing ZIF-8@ZIF-67 [270]. The produced cell potential for CoP/NCNHP at 10 mA cm−2 was 1.64 V. Experiments and DFT calculations revealed that the intense cooperative coupling of CoP with N-doped carbon nanotube hollow polyhedrons helped to strengthen the catalytic performance. In addition, the CoP/NCNHP catalyst with unique hollow structure had high specific surface areas and could offer more catalytically active sites. 5.3.2 Incorporating carbon materials Since the insertion of conductive carbon materials can further promote the transfer of charge from the conductive support to the surface of the electrocatalyst, the combination of MOF and conductive matrix (graphene, carbon nanotubes, etc.) can generate electrocatalysts with high catalytic performance [271,272]. Jiang et al. adopted graphene oxide (GO) as a template to in-situ grow ZIF-67, and then prepared CoP/rGO layered composites by pyrolysis and phosphating ZIF-67/GO [271]. They found that ZIF-67 was able to grow on both sides of the sheet-like GO template to form sheet-like ZIF-67/GO. The as-obtained CoP/rGO still maintained the sheet-like morphology. In 1.0 M KOH, CoP/rGO presented prominent electrochemical activity (HER: η 10 = 104 mV, OER: η 10 = 320 mV). The strengthened activity was derived from the insertion of RGO with the sheet-like structure that could significantly improve the conductivity of the catalyst. Zhao et al. grew a nickel MOF (MOF-74-Ni) on GO and converted the precursor to Ni2P/rGO by phosphating (Fig. 14f) [272]. The derived ultrasmall Ni2P NPs were firmly embedded in the RGO layer. Thanks to the specific interface interaction between GO and MOF-74-Ni, Ni2P/rGO is rich in evenly dispersed highly exposed catalytic sites, achieving a cell potential of 1.61 V at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 14g and h). 5.3.3 Fabricating self-supporting electrodes The TMP-based self-supporting electrodes can be constructed via directly constructing MOFs on an electroconductive carrier, which generally display outstanding electrocatalytic performance [273–278]. As the derived metal phosphide catalysts are tightly and firmly anchored to the electroconductive carrier, the stability of the working electrode, the catalytic sites and the conductivity of the catalyst can be significantly improved. Moreover, fabricating self-supporting electrodes can avoid the use of expensive conductive polymer binders, saving costs and time [279]. Manthiram et al. fabricated carbon-inserted Ni-Fe phosphide on NF as a self-supporting electrode for electrolysis of water [280]. The preparation process was as follows (Fig. 15 a). Firstly, NiFe oxyhydroxide nanosheets (NiFe LDH) were grown on NF. Bimetal Ni-Fe MOF nanorods were then prepared via the combination of an organic ligand with NiFe LDH. Finally, the Ni-Fe MOF nanorods were transformed into porous Ni-Fe phosphide (Ni-Fe-P@C) after phosphating. The cell potential for the as-obtained Ni-Fe-P@C self-supporting electrode at 10 mA cm−2 was merely 1.52 V (Fig. 15b and c). The excellent catalytic property of Ni-Fe-P@C originated from the following aspects. (1) The growth of carbon-inserted nanorods directly on a conductive foamed nickel substrate could promote electron transfer. (2) Carbon generated in-situ could reduce agglomeration of active sites of phosphide. (3) The MOF-derived highly porous structure had highly exposed catalytic sites, and facilitated contact with the electrolyte and gas release. CC has high electrical conductivity and excellent flexibility and mechanical strength. It is often used as a conductive substrate to build self-supporting electrodes [281,282]. Lan et al. fabricated CoP/MoP@NC on CC for overall water splitting (Fig. 15d) [281]. Firstly, polyoxometalate-based MOFs (PMo12-Co/Zn-ZIFs) were hot-pressed on CC.
