Subsequently, CoP/MoP@NC/CC was prepared via phosphating PMo12-Co/Zn-ZIFs/CC. The self-supporting CoP/MoP@NC/CC electrode exhibited great electrochemical activity in 1.0 M KOH, yielding a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at overpotentials of 94 mV for HER and 270 mV for OER (Fig. 15e and f). Wang et al. directly grew ZIF-L-Co nanosheets on commercial CC, and then prepared CoP nanosheets (CoP NS/CC) by subsequent heat treatment and phosphating (Fig. 15g) [282]. The unique porous nanosheet architecture afforded the self-supporting electrode great surface permeability, rich catalytic sites and enhanced electron conductivity. Therefore, the CoP NS/CC self-supporting electrode exhibited outstanding electrocatalytic performance 1.0 M KOH, affording a current density of 10 mA cm−2 through employing a cell potential of 1.67 V, along with long-term stability (Fig. 15h and i). 6 Conclusions and perspectives This review presented the latest developments in the electrocatalytic water splitting of MOF-derived TMPs. MOF materials possess natural advantages in composition adjustment and structural optimization. The coordination configuration, species and ratio of metal ions in MOFs can be precisely tuned at the atomic level. Using metal doping to control the electronic structure of catalytic centers can effectively strengthen the inherent reactivity of the catalyst. Moreover, various morphologies of MOFs such as nanotubes, nanowires, nanorods, and nanosheets can be constructed under different preparation conditions through various types of ligands and metal centers, thereby deriving more reactive TMPs. Furthermore, the in-situ converted carbon layer by the organic ligands can not only protect the TMPs from being etched by strongly acidic and alkaline media, but also avoid agglomeration of the catalysts during the catalytic process, thereby promoting their activity and stability. In particular, heteroatom-containing ligands can incorporate N, S or P atoms into the carbon layer after conversion, thus providing more catalytic sites. Therefore, the catalytic properties of MOF-derived TMPs can be optimized through component regulation (metal regulation and ligand regulation) and morphology regulation. Using these strategies, novel multifunctional and highly active energy products based on MOF-derived TMP will emerge in the future. In spite of the great achievements, the application of TMPs derived from MOFs in electrolyzed water still faces numerous obstacles. (1) Currently, the majority of MOF-derived TMPs exhibit high efficiency in alkaline medium. It is extremely rare for TMPs to exhibit good OER performance in acidic media, which will reduce their potential for application in acidic systems. (2) The preparation of ultrafine TMP nanocrystals with a size of less than 2.0 nm has not yet been achieved. Ultrafine nanocrystals smaller than 2.0 nm have near the limit of exposed catalytically active sites, so they usually exhibit excellent catalytic performance. At present, the synthesized TMP nanocrystals are generally larger than 5.0 nm, the construction of ultrafine yet stable metal phosphide nanocrystals in cluster-level is still a great challenge. (3) The lack of highly active TMPs drive total hydrolysis with large current densities. The basic requirement for the industrialization of electrocatalysts is the application of low overpotentials to obtain high current densities in electrolytic water (>500 mA cm−2). Currently, few TMPs derived from MOFs meet the requirement. (4) The exact catalytic mechanism and the actual catalytic active sites of MOF-derived TMPs for HER and OER require to be further revealed. Currently, the catalytic mechanism was generally deduced by combining the structure/morphology of the catalysts with the theoretical simulations. In fact, the catalytic mechanism and configuration changes can be well revealed through in-situ characterization techniques. However, in-situ characterization techniques are very scarce for HER and OER. Overall, the development of catalysts with better catalytic performance and an in-depth understanding of their catalytic mechanism require further efforts. The following breakthroughs in this field may be focused on. (1) In-situ characterization tests coupled with theoretical calculations reveal the actual catalytic active sites and reaction mechanisms of HER and OER, so as to provide theoretical instructions for the construction of efficient TMP-based electrocatalysts. In-situ characterization techniques commonly include in-situ PXRD, in-situ TEM, in-situ XAS, in-situ FTIR, in-situ XPS, in-situ Raman, in-situ electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), and so on. It is critical to uncover the association between the actual active site and catalytic activity. Since TMPs can occur self-reconstruction during OER, it is strongly recommended to exploit in-situ characterization techniques to unveil the real catalytic sites and probe the catalytic pathways. On one hand, in-situ characterization techniques enable to shed light on the electronic states and shapes of the catalyst in catalysis, which is useful for grasping the fundamentals of the entire catalysis. On the other hand, they can accurately determine the dynamic chemistry of the real active sites as well as the key reaction intermediates, furnishing theoretical instructions for the precise-design of highly active sites. (2) The introduction of multiple types of metal atoms regulates the electronic structure and coordination microenvironment of the catalytic sites, thereby further improving its inherent catalytic performance. Cluster-based MOFs with different nuclear numbers provide a platform for atomic-level control of the metal composition and ratio (Fig. 16 ). For example, the coordination configuration, content of metal centers and species in multinuclear MOF materials can be precisely controlled. The multi-metal coupling and synergistic catalytic effect in metal phosphides derived from multinuclear MOFs will provide more possibilities for improving their catalytic performance. (3) With reference to the synthesis methods of single atomic catalysts [283], the metal content in the MOF precursor is precisely controlled to prepare metal clusters smaller than 2 nm. Finally, ultrafine TMPs may be able to prepare by phosphating treatment, thereby improving their catalytic activity. (4) At present, the synthesis cost of many MOFs is relatively high and it is difficult to mass-produce. Therefore, the large-scale preparation of MOFs can greatly reduce the synthesis cost of TMPs. In particular, the large-scale preparation of P-containing MOFs can eliminate the use of additional P sources such as NaH2PO2, thereby reducing the generation of large amounts of highly toxic gases. He is currently a lecturer at Jiangxi Normal University (JXNU). His research interest focuses on the development of highly active electrocatalysts for water splitting and carbon dioxide reduction. Jia Zhang received her Ph.D. degree from Huazhong Agricultural University in 2018. She is currently a lecturer at JXNU. Her research interest focuses on the synthesis and applications of biomass-derived catalysts and molecule-based confinement chemistry. Li-Wen Ding received her Master degree from Hunan Normal University in 2004. She is currently an experimenter at JXNU. Her research interest focuses on molecule-based nanomaterials for catalysis. Zi-Yi Du received his Ph.D. degree from Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2007. He is currently a professor at JXNU. His research interest focuses on molecular-based confinement chemistry and the related mechanism as well as functionalities. Chun-Ting He obtained his B.S. and Ph.D. degrees (supervisor: Prof. Xiao-Ming Chen) from Sun Yat-sen University (SYSU) in 2011 and 2016, respectively. He had been a visiting research fellow at Tsinghua University and Griffith University (Australia) during 2015 and 2017, respectively. He continued to be a postdoctoral fellow at SYSU until 2018 by the support of “National Postdoctoral Program for Innovative Talents” (China), and then was selected into the “Young Elite Scientists Sponsorship Program” by CAST. He is currently a professor of the College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at JXNU. His research interest focuses on molecule-based confinement chemistry and energy catalysis.

coredata.dc:description: It is critical to synthesize high-efficiency electrocatalysts to boost the performance of water splitting to meet the requirements of industrial applications. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) can function as ideal molecular platforms for the design of highly reactive transition metal phosphides (TMPs), a kind of candidates for high-efficiently electrocatalytic water splitting. The intrinsic activity of the electrocatalysts can be greatly improved via modulating the electronic structure of the catalytic center through the MOF precursors/templates. Moreover, the carbon layer converted in-situ by the organic ligands can not only protect the TMPs from being degraded in the harsh electrochemical environments, but also avoid agglomeration of the catalysts, thereby promoting their activities and stabilities. Furthermore, heteroatom-containing ligands can incorporate N, S or P, etc. atoms into the carbon matrixes after conversion, regulating the coordination microenvironments of the active centers as well as their electronic structures. In this review, we first summarized the latest developments in MOF-derived TMPs by the unique advantages in metal, organic ligand, and morphology regulations for electrocatalytic water splitting. Secondly, we concluded the critical scientific issues currently facing for designing state-of-the-art TMP-based electrocatalysts. Finally, we presented an outlook on this research area, encompassing electrocatalyst construction, catalytic mechanism research, etc.
